name: Context
comment: An instantiable class for manipulating paths. Unlike the top-level functions, this lets you explicitly select what platform the paths will use.

style.name: style
style.comment: The style of path that this context works with.

current.name: current
current.comment: The current directory that relative paths will be relative to.

separator.name: separator
separator.comment: Gets the path separator for the context's path/path.Context.style. On Mac and Linux, this is /. On Windows, it's \.

constructors.comment:
Creates a new path context for the given style and current directory.

If path/path.Context.Context-.style is omitted, it uses the host operating system's path style. If only path/path.Context.Context-.current is omitted, it defaults ".". If both path/path.Context.Context-.style and path/path.Context.Context-.current are omitted, path/path.Context.Context-.current defaults to the real current working directory.

On the browser, path/path.Context.Context-.style defaults to path/path-style.Style.url and path/path.Context.Context-.current defaults to the current URL.

absolute.name: absolute
absolute.comment:
Creates a new path by appending the given path parts to path/path.Context.current. Equivalent to join() with path/path.Context.current as the first argument. Example:

var context = new Context(current: '/root');
context.absolute('path', 'to', 'foo'); // -> '/root/path/to/foo'

If path/path.Context.current isn't absolute, this won't return an absolute path.

basename.name: basename
basename.comment:
Gets the part of path/path.Context.basename.path after the last separator on the context's platform.

context.basename('path/to/foo.dart'); // -> 'foo.dart'
context.basename('path/to');          // -> 'to'

Trailing separators are ignored.

context.basename('path/to/'); // -> 'to'

basenameWithoutExtension.name: basenameWithoutExtension
basenameWithoutExtension.comment:
Gets the part of path/path.Context.basenameWithoutExtension.path after the last separator on the context's platform, and without any trailing file extension.

context.basenameWithoutExtension('path/to/foo.dart'); // -> 'foo'

Trailing separators are ignored.

context.basenameWithoutExtension('path/to/foo.dart/'); // -> 'foo'

dirname.name: dirname
dirname.comment:
Gets the part of path/path.Context.dirname.path before the last separator.

context.dirname('path/to/foo.dart'); // -> 'path/to'
context.dirname('path/to');          // -> 'path'

Trailing separators are ignored.

context.dirname('path/to/'); // -> 'path'

extension.name: extension
extension.comment:
Gets the file extension of path/path.Context.extension.path: the portion of path/path.Context.basename from the last . to the end (including the . itself).

context.extension('path/to/foo.dart'); // -> '.dart'
context.extension('path/to/foo'); // -> ''
context.extension('path.to/foo'); // -> ''
context.extension('path/to/foo.dart.js'); // -> '.js'

If the file name starts with a ., then it is not considered an extension:

context.extension('~/.bashrc');    // -> ''
context.extension('~/.notes.txt'); // -> '.txt'

rootPrefix.name: rootPrefix
rootPrefix.comment:
Returns the root of path/path.Context.rootPrefix.path if it's absolute, or an empty string if it's relative.

// Unix
context.rootPrefix('path/to/foo'); // -> ''
context.rootPrefix('/path/to/foo'); // -> '/'

// Windows
context.rootPrefix(r'path\to\foo'); // -> ''
context.rootPrefix(r'C:\path\to\foo'); // -> r'C:\'

// URL
context.rootPrefix('path/to/foo'); // -> ''
context.rootPrefix('http://dartlang.org/path/to/foo');
  // -> 'http://dartlang.org'

isAbsolute.name: isAbsolute
isAbsolute.comment:
Returns true if path/path.Context.isAbsolute.path is an absolute path and false if it is a relative path.

On POSIX systems, absolute paths start with a / (forward slash). On Windows, an absolute path starts with \\, or a drive letter followed by :/ or :\. For URLs, absolute paths either start with a protocol and optional hostname (e.g. http://dartlang.org, file://) or with a /.

URLs that start with / are known as "root-relative", since they're relative to the root of the current URL. Since root-relative paths are still absolute in every other sense, path/path.Context.isAbsolute will return true for them. They can be detected using path/path.Context.isRootRelative.

isRelative.name: isRelative
isRelative.comment: Returns true if path/path.Context.isRelative.path is a relative path and false if it is absolute. On POSIX systems, absolute paths start with a / (forward slash). On Windows, an absolute path starts with \\, or a drive letter followed by :/ or :\.

isRootRelative.name: isRootRelative
isRootRelative.comment:
Returns true if path/path.Context.isRootRelative.path is a root-relative path and false if it's not.

URLs that start with / are known as "root-relative", since they're relative to the root of the current URL. Since root-relative paths are still absolute in every other sense, path/path.Context.isAbsolute will return true for them. They can be detected using path/path.Context.isRootRelative.

No POSIX and Windows paths are root-relative.

join.name: join
join.comment:
Joins the given path parts into a single path. Example:

context.join('path', 'to', 'foo'); // -> 'path/to/foo'

If any part ends in a path separator, then a redundant separator will not be added:

context.join('path/', 'to', 'foo'); // -> 'path/to/foo

If a part is an absolute path, then anything before that will be ignored:

context.join('path', '/to', 'foo'); // -> '/to/foo'

joinAll.name: joinAll
joinAll.comment:
Joins the given path parts into a single path. Example:

context.joinAll(['path', 'to', 'foo']); // -> 'path/to/foo'

If any part ends in a path separator, then a redundant separator will not be added:

context.joinAll(['path/', 'to', 'foo']); // -> 'path/to/foo

If a part is an absolute path, then anything before that will be ignored:

context.joinAll(['path', '/to', 'foo']); // -> '/to/foo'

For a fixed number of parts, path/path.Context.join is usually terser.

split.name: split
split.comment:
Splits path/path.Context.split.path into its components using the current platform's path/path.Context.separator. Example:

context.split('path/to/foo'); // -> ['path', 'to', 'foo']

The path will not be normalized before splitting.

context.split('path/../foo'); // -> ['path', '..', 'foo']

If path/path.Context.split.path is absolute, the root directory will be the first element in the array. Example:

// Unix
context.split('/path/to/foo'); // -> ['/', 'path', 'to', 'foo']

// Windows
context.split(r'C:\path\to\foo'); // -> [r'C:\', 'path', 'to', 'foo']

normalize.name: normalize
normalize.comment:
Normalizes path/path.Context.normalize.path, simplifying it by handling .., and ., and removing redundant path separators whenever possible.

context.normalize('path/./to/..//file.text'); // -> 'path/file.txt'

relative.name: relative
relative.comment:
Attempts to convert path/path.Context.relative.path to an equivalent relative path relative to root.

var context = new Context(current: '/root/path');
context.relative('/root/path/a/b.dart'); // -> 'a/b.dart'
context.relative('/root/other.dart'); // -> '../other.dart'

If the path/path.Context.relative.from argument is passed, path/path.Context.relative.path is made relative to that instead.

context.relative('/root/path/a/b.dart',
    from: '/root/path'); // -> 'a/b.dart'
context.relative('/root/other.dart',
    from: '/root/path'); // -> '../other.dart'

If path/path.Context.relative.path and/or path/path.Context.relative.from are relative paths, they are assumed to be relative to path/path.Context.current.

Since there is no relative path from one drive letter to another on Windows, this will return an absolute path in that case.

context.relative(r'D:\other', from: r'C:\other'); // -> 'D:\other'

This will also return an absolute path if an absolute path/path.Context.relative.path is passed to a context with a relative path for path/path.Context.current.

var context = new Context(r'some/relative/path');
context.relative(r'/absolute/path'); // -> '/absolute/path'

If root is relative, it may be impossible to determine a path from path/path.Context.relative.from to path/path.Context.relative.path. For example, if root and path/path.Context.relative.path are "." and path/path.Context.relative.from is "/", no path can be determined. In this case, a path/path.PathException will be thrown.

isWithin.name: isWithin
isWithin.comment:
Returns true if path/path.Context.isWithin.child is a path beneath parent, and false otherwise.

path.isWithin('/root/path', '/root/path/a'); // -> true
path.isWithin('/root/path', '/root/other'); // -> false
path.isWithin('/root/path', '/root/path'); // -> false

withoutExtension.name: withoutExtension
withoutExtension.comment:
Removes a trailing extension from the last part of path/path.Context.withoutExtension.path.

context.withoutExtension('path/to/foo.dart'); // -> 'path/to/foo'

fromUri.name: fromUri
fromUri.comment:
Returns the path represented by path/path.Context.fromUri.uri, which may be a dart-core.String or a dart-core.Uri.

For POSIX and Windows styles, path/path.Context.fromUri.uri must be a file: URI. For the URL style, this will just convert path/path.Context.fromUri.uri to a string.

// POSIX
context.fromUri('file:///path/to/foo')
  // -> '/path/to/foo'

// Windows
context.fromUri('file:///C:/path/to/foo')
  // -> r'C:\path\to\foo'

// URL
context.fromUri('http://dartlang.org/path/to/foo')
  // -> 'http://dartlang.org/path/to/foo'

If path/path.Context.fromUri.uri is relative, a relative path will be returned.

path.fromUri('path/to/foo'); // -> 'path/to/foo'

toUri.name: toUri
toUri.comment:
Returns the URI that represents path/path.Context.toUri.path.

For POSIX and Windows styles, this will return a file: URI. For the URL style, this will just convert path/path.Context.toUri.path to a dart-core.Uri.

// POSIX
context.toUri('/path/to/foo')
  // -> Uri.parse('file:///path/to/foo')

// Windows
context.toUri(r'C:\path\to\foo')
  // -> Uri.parse('file:///C:/path/to/foo')

// URL
context.toUri('http://dartlang.org/path/to/foo')
  // -> Uri.parse('http://dartlang.org/path/to/foo')

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides path/path.Context.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and path/path.Context.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the path/path.Context.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
path/path.Context.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to path/path.Context.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If path/path.Context.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of path/path.Context.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
